speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these feeding difficulties? How long have you noticed them, and what happens when you try to feed the child?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama gets really upset when I cry and she tries to feed me. It doesn't feel good when she puts the bottle in my mouth, and I just push it away."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me where it hurts when your mom tries to feed you? Is it in your mouth, throat, or somewhere else?

speaker: Patient
text: "Owwww! *cries* It hurts here! *points to belly* When Mama tries to feed me, I feel like something is squeezing my tummy and it makes me cry."

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like the feeding difficulties are related to the abdominal pain. Can you tell me more about this sensation of something squeezing your tummy? Is it a sharp pain or a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels like someone is giving me a big hug, but it's not a nice hug. It's a yucky hug that makes me want to cry."

speaker: Doctor
text: So it's a vague, uncomfortable sensation in your belly that makes you feel like you're being hugged tightly. Can you tell me if this sensation happens all the time, or is it only when your mom tries to feed you?

speaker: Patient
text: "It happens sometimes when Mama picks me up or when she puts me down. It's not always when she's feeding me, but it makes me cry when it does happen during feeding."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where on your belly you feel this sensation of being hugged tightly? Is it more on one side or all over?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more on my left side. *points to left side of belly* When Mama holds me or puts me down, it feels like it's happening here. And when she feeds me, it feels like it's getting worse."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever had any vomiting or diarrhea with these symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, no, no! *shakes head* I don't throw up or have yucky poop. But sometimes... *pauses*...I get really, really mad and I scream a lot. Mama says it's because I'm upset, but I don't know why I'm so mad."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these times when you get really mad and scream a lot? Is there anything specific that happens before you start screaming?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't know, it just happens! *cries* Sometimes it happens when Mama is holding me or when she's trying to feed me. It's like... *pauses*...it's like something is inside me and it's making me mad! *cries harder*"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of something being inside you that's making you mad? Is it a physical sensation or more of an emotional feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like... *pauses*...it's like a big, yucky feeling in my tummy. It makes me want to scream and cry. I don't know why it's there, but it makes me feel icky."

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're experiencing some discomfort and pain in your belly, especially on your left side. Can you tell me if you've ever had any episodes of constipation or hard stools?

speaker: Patient
text: *whimpers* "I don't know... *pauses*...I don't think so... *cries* Sometimes it feels like my poop is stuck, but Mama says it's okay because I'm still gaining weight..."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these times when you feel like your poop is stuck? Does it happen frequently or is it an occasional thing?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mama says it's okay when it happens, but it makes me feel ouchie inside. It happens sometimes, but not all the time. I don't like it when it does happen, it makes me feel... *pauses*...yucky."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of being yucky when you have trouble passing stool? Is it a physical sensation or more of an emotional feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels... *pauses*...like my tummy is mad at me. It's like it's saying, 'No, no, no! You can't go potty right now!' And it makes me feel sad and ouchie inside. I don't like it when it happens."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever had any episodes of blood in your stool or black tarry stools?

speaker: Patient
text: "Ewww, no! *shakes head* Mama says that's bad and we don't want that to happen. I don't like the way it sounds. *cries*"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me your belly again and point to the exact spot where you feel this sensation of being hugged tightly?

speaker: Patient
text: *points to left side of belly* "Owwww, right here! *cries* It's like someone is squeezing my tummy again!"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the sensation of being hugged tightly in your belly gets better or worse when you have a bowel movement?

speaker: Patient
text: "It gets a little better... *pauses*...but it doesn't go away completely. Sometimes when I go potty, it feels like the hug is a little less tight, but it's still there. It's like... *pauses*...the hug is still holding onto me, but it's not as strong."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the hug holding onto you after you've had a bowel movement? Is it like the hug is still present, but it's just not as intense?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like... *pauses*...the hug is still there, but it's not squeezing me as hard. It's like... *pauses*...it's giving me a little break, but it's not going away completely. Sometimes, when I go potty, it feels like the hug is getting a little weaker, but it's still there. It's like... *pauses*...it's still holding onto me, but it's not as strong."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of the hug getting weaker after you've had a bowel movement? Does it feel like the hug is slowly releasing its grip on your belly?

speaker: Patient
text: "Mmm... *pauses*...yes! It feels like the hug is slowly letting go. It's like... *pauses*...it's giving me a little bit of relief, but it's not going away completely. Sometimes, when I go potty, it feels like the hug is saying, 'Okay, okay, I'll let you go for a little bit.' But then it starts to squeeze me again, and I feel ouchie inside."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when the hug starts to squeeze you again after you've had a bowel movement? Does it feel like the sensation gets worse or stays the same?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels like... *pauses*...the hug is getting stronger again. It's like... *pauses*...it's trying to hold onto me again. Sometimes, when I go potty, it feels like the hug is saying, 'No, no, no! You can't go potty right now!' And it makes me feel ouchie inside again. Mama says it's okay, but I don't like it when it happens."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what happens when the hug gets stronger again after you've had a bowel movement? Does it feel like it's related to the sensation of being held or squeezed in your belly?

speaker: Patient
text: "It feels like... *pauses*...the hug is getting tighter again. It's like... *pauses*...it's trying to hold onto me even harder. Sometimes, when I go potty, it feels like the hug is saying, 'No, no, no! You can't go potty right now!' And it makes me feel ouchie inside again. Mama says it's okay, but I don't like it when it happens. *cries*"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've ever had any episodes where the hug feels like it's completely gone away, and your belly feels normal again?

speaker: Patient
text: *sniffles* "Y-yes... *pauses*...sometimes it feels like the hug is gone, and my tummy feels normal again. It's like... *pauses*...it's like a big, yucky cloud is gone, and I feel happy and not ouchie inside. Mama says it's okay when it happens, and she gives me a big hug and says everything is okay. *smiles slightly*"

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the patient's symptoms and responses, I'm going to request some test results to help me narrow down the diagnosis. REQUEST TEST: Abdominal X-Ray Can you please tell me more about the sensation of being hugged tightly in your belly? Is it a constant feeling or does it come and go?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Abdominal X-Ray: Dilated bowel segments with absence of gas in the rectum, suggesting a possible obstruction.
